event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item: Schedule a repair procedure to replace the affected disk. Use fmdump -v -u <EVENT_ID> to identify the disk.
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: SMART health-monitoring firmware reported that a disk failure is imminent.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
This message indicates that the %DISTRO% Fault Manager has received reports from the SMART (Self-Monitoring, Analysis and Reporting Technology) health-monitoring firmware indicating a disk failure is imminent.

The recommended service action for this event is to schedule replacement of the affected Disk Drive at the earliest possible convenience. Although the Disk Drive may be functioning, it is not intended nor recommended that the faulted Disk Drive remain in the system for a prolonged period of time.

Follow the steps below to complete the recommended repair action. 

    NOTE:For the examples below:
RED   HIGHLIGHT = Sun Message ID
BLUE  HIGHLIGHT = UUID or EVENT_ID
GREEN HIGHLIGHT = FRU
Step 1: Find the 36 character UUID string associated with thefault.

It can be located using several methods. Use either the fmdump (1M) or fmadm (1M) command shown in Example 1.1 below, or extract the UUID from the fault message displayed in the console output at the time of the fault.

Note: Be sure to get the correct 36 character UUID string (highlighted in blue) if more than one is listed. You can identify the correct string by associating the fault with the date and time stamp in Example 1.1 below) from the fmdump output. The fmadm faulty output also shows the UUID (highlighted in blue).

    Example 1.1 - finding the UUID (36 character string): 
    # fmdump
TIME                 UUID                                 SUNW-MSG-ID
May 08 16:01:43.9265 5a9e5915-250b-c9b9-ddb2-df99af529a11 DISK-8000-0X
Sep 13 06:01:43.9332 1c13b3fe-ceb7-6cff-d9cd-8527db6a0d88 DISK-8000-2J
Jun 08 14:01:43.9404 43e391a3-94a2-e846-aebe-ef0beffacc1a DISK-8000-12

    # fmadm faulty
   STATE RESOURCE / UUID
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 degraded dev:///:devid=id1,sd@SATA_____HITACHI_HDS7225S______VDS41DT4F0823J//pci@0,0/pci1022,7458@1/pci11ab,11ab@1/disk@0,0
         5a9e5915-250b-c9b9-ddb2-df99af529a11
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Step 2: Use the command; fmdump -v -u UUID, to locate the faulty Disk Drive, where UUID consists of the 36 character string obtained in Step 1 above. The FRU (highlighted in green) identifies the faulty Disk Drive. See Example 2.1 below.

    Example 2.1 - determining which FRU (Disk Drive) needs to be replaced: 
    # fmdump -v -u 5a9e5915-250b-c9b9-ddb2-df99af529a11
TIME                 UUID                                 SUNW-MSG-ID
May 08 16:01:43.9404 5a9e5915-250b-c9b9-ddb2-df99af529a11 DISK-8000-0X
  100%  fault.io.disk.predictive-failure

        Problem in: hc:///:serial=VDK41BT4C7PJYS:part=HITACHI-HDS7225SBSUN250G-527N7PJYS:
                           revision=V44OA81A/motherboard=0/hostbridge=2/pcibus=9/pcidev=8
                           /pcifn=0/pcibus=11/pcidev=1/pcifn=0/sata-port=6/disk=0
           Affects: dev:///:devid=id1,sd@SATA_____HITACHI_HDS7225S______VDS41DT4F0823J//pci@0,0/pci1022,7458@1/pci11ab,11ab@1/disk@0,0
               FRU: hc:///:serial=VDK41BT4C7PJYS:part=HITACHI-HDS7225SBSUN250G-527N7PJYS:
                           revision=V44OA81A/motherboard=0/hostbridge=2/pcibus=9/pcidev=8
                           /pcifn=0/pcibus=11/pcidev=1/pcifn=0/sata-port=6/disk=0
          Location: HD_ID_29

Step 3: Identify the FRU that needs to be replaced.

On supported platforms, the FRU will contain an identifier in the 'FRU' label (highlighted in green above). In our example, the service action would be to replace the Disk located in slot 29, as the HD_ID identified in the string is HD_ID_29. On platforms where this information isn't available, the user should refer to platform-specific documentation for identifying which physical location corresponds to the failed device.

Step 4: Replacing the faulty FRU (repairing the faulted resource).

Refer to your specific Platform's Hardware Maintenance Manual or service label for proper disk replacement procedures. These procedures can include software manipulation to prepare the disk for replacement; e.g. umounting filesystems, disk management considerations, cfgadm commands, etc...

Step 5: Verify the repaired resource is no longer faulty

After the Disk Drive has been replaced, use the %DISTRO% command 'fmadm faulty' to display all faulted resources in the system. Confirm that the repaired resource is no longer listed as faulted. See Example 5.1.

    Example 5.1 - verifying the repaired resource is no longer faulty: 
    # fmadm faulty
   STATE RESOURCE / UUID
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
